It was a case that divided America - literally - into North and South.
One hundred and fifty years ago, the U.S.
Supreme Court told the enslaved Dred Scott that he had no legal right to freedom.
Scott had sued his owners, arguing that they had kept him in states where slavery was illegal.
The high court's verdict rocked the country and intensified calls for war.
This week, Harvard Law School is hosting a symposium on the Dred Scott case.
In a moment, we'll hear from the man behind the symposium, Harvard law professor Charles Ogletree.
But first, it's easy to forget that historical figures like Dred Scott aren't just abstract ideas.
He was a real man with a real family.
His great, great granddaughter Lynne Jackson still lives in the St. Louis area, where Scott brought his suit.
She joins me now.
Lynne, welcome.
Thank you for having me.
It's quite an honor and a pleasure to be with you today.
It took enormous courage to do what your great, great grandfather did.
Can you give us any sense of how your family thinks of Dred Scott the man as opposed to Dred Scott the historical figure?
Well, obviously we're very proud of Dred and Harriet both.
They both filed a petition together on April 6th of 1846.

And this wasn't uncommon, but it was very uncommon for them to go 11 years and through five trials, so we are very grateful and very thankful for them that they had the courage to do this, that they were willing to take it as far as they took it.
It shows a great deal of tenacity and personal character and virtue that we feel is still a part of who we hope we are today.
You mentioned Harriet.
Can you very briefly give us a sense of the way that Dred and Harriet tried to escape?
It is a fascinating story.
Well, their first effort was that they went to the owner's widow, which was Irene Emerson.

After Dr. Emerson passed away and they had saved money and thought, well, we'll purchase our freedom, because all through this story, you get a sense that Dred wanted to do it like any other man would do it.
But she said no. So the next move was, well, we will take it to the courts.
The first case was a mistrial because of hearsays.
The second trial, they actually won their freedom - a lot of people don't realize they actually did win their freedom in a jury of 12 white men - but it was immediately appealed and then overturned.
At that point, it seemed that - the Missouri Supreme Court said that they were willing to accept the consequences of slavery within her borders.
There was no other recourse.
But Roswell Field came to the plate and hit a homerun and said, look, there's a diversity clause here that we can use.
So it went to the Supreme Court, and I just say that for all these years and for all these efforts, you have to think about every time they had to make a decision, should we go on, should we stop?
What's the good for their children?
What's going to be the outcome of this?
And it was difficult.
It was very difficult.
Dred only lived a year and a half after that case.
Fortunately, Taylor Blow was able to buy their freedom bond, and so they did die free people.
So you have two children, one of whom has actually portrayed Dred Scott in a school play.
What do you tell them about their lineage?
Well, what our family usually says in no modest way is that we're very honored, but they did what they did, and it's up to us to do what we have to do.
Everybody is born with a purpose.
And although we want to do like they did, we can't do the same things that they did.
But we can do it the same way.
We can do it with a virtue and character that had to be there for them to endure this.

And that they need to understand the significance of our case, that without this outcome, there might not have been Civil War, and therefore there may not have been the 13th, 14th and 15th Amendments.
And we could still be a slave nation.
So the focus we have this year for our Dred Scott Heritage Foundation is education, that we would like everyone to know this case and understand it.
Well, Lynne, thank you so much for joining us.

I feel thrilled.
